descriptionSet.description: The cutout figures of Radha (or Gopi) and Krishna are placed into a European landscape, seated on a rock inmidst a hilly lush lanscape with view on sea and city by coastline. The landscape-picture is surrounded by a damaged wooden frame.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

titleSet.title: Krishna and Radha in European landscape

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: The cutout figures of Radha (or Gopi) and Krishna are placed into a European landscape, seated on a rock inmidst a hilly lush lanscape with view on sea and city by coastline. The landscape-picture is surrounded by a damaged wooden frame.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This image provides examples of another approach, where the consumer has created a three-dimensional (Indian-style) understanding of landscape by adding cut-out figures of Radha and Krishna onto a poster or calendar-art piece that showed a European-style landscape. (Sandria B. Freitag) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Probably from the "Art Publishing Co., Calcutta" (see Jain 2004). Pastoral scene set in picturesque Italy, possibly a German print. These scenes were common in Bengali prints of the early twentieth century, as well as the style of collage was 'trendy' at that time. Jain calls them 'Indo-German collages of the Krishnalila' (2004: 84), and refers to other backdrops such as Switzerland (Lake Geneva), Scotland, Germany (e.g. Rheinstein). Many merchants of Shekavati (in which the images were hanging) and Bhiwani "had business offices in Calcutta from where they brought colonial noveltie to their country homes" (ibid: 78).() (cb)
related literature: Jain, Jyotindra. 2004. Indian Popular Culture. 'The Conquest of the World as Picture'. Delhi: National Gallery of Modern Art (gs)
related literature: Braudel, Fernand 1981. "The Structures of Everyday Life". London: Collins. (gs)
